P. 298</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:5" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam libet hirsutam tibi falce recidere barbam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:766" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 766</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abradere,</quote> <trans><tr>to clip off</tr>.</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 162</bibl></cit>; cf. Baumg.Crus. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:45" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">rasitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 4</bibl></cit>: barbam vellere alicui, <hi rend="ital">to pluck one by the beard</hi> (an insult), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 133</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sapientem pascere barbam,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to study the Stoic philosophy</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:133" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 133</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:2:28" default="NO">2, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">capillatior quam ante barbāque majore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 5, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:25:section=62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 25, § 62</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in gens et cana barba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 10, 6</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes in <number>plur.</number> of a heavy, long beard, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 99, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 157, 1</bibl>.—The statues of the gods had barbas aureas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:34:83" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 34, 83</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, barbam auream habere = deum esse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 58, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:2:56" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 2, 56</bibl>.—The ancient Romans allowed the beard to grow long (hence, barbati, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:14:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 14, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:23:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 23, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:103" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 103</bibl>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">dignus barbā capillisque Majorum, of an upright, honest man,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:16:31" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 16, 31</bibl></cit>), until A.U.C. 454, when a certain P. Titinius Menas brought barbers to Rome from Sicily, and introduced the custom of shaving the beard, Varr R. R. 2, 11, 10; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:211" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 59, 59, § 211</bibl>. Scipio Africanus was the first who caused himself to be shaved daily, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 1</bibl>. 1. Still, this custom seems to have become general first in the Aug. per.; cf. Boettig. Sabina, 2, p. 57 sq.; Goer. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:23:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 23, 62</bibl>.—Young men allowed the beard to grow for some years; <cit><quote lang="la">hence. juvenes barbatuli or bene barbati (v. barbatulus and barbatus). It was the custom to devote the first beard cut off to some deity, esp. to Apollo, Jupiter, or Venus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:186" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 186</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4930.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4930.2" n="A" level="2"> Of animals: <cit><quote lang="la">hircorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 17, 37, § 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caprarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 8, 30, § 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gallinaceorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 11, 29, § 97</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luporum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 8, 42</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n4930.3" n="B" level="2"> Of plants, <hi rend="ital">the wool</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nucum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 22, 24, § 89</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 17, 23, 35, § 202</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4930.4" n="C" level="2"> Barba Jovis, <hi rend="ital">a shrub</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the silver-leaved woolblade</hi>: Anthyllis barba Jovis, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 18, 31, § 76</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4931" type="main" key="Barba2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4931.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman name</hi>, e. g. Cassius Barba, <hi rend="ital">a friend of Cœsar and Antony</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:1:2 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 1, 2 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:52:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 52, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barbana: <entryFree id="n4932" type="main" key="Barba_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barbāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4932.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Illyria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:31:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 31, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barbara: <entryFree id="n4933" type="main" key="barba^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbăra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. barbarus, II. B. <sense id="n4933.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
barbare: <entryFree id="n4934" type="main" key="barba^re_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. barbarus <sense id="n4934.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
barbari: <entryFree id="n4935" type="main" key="barba^ri"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbări</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, v. barbarus.</entryFree>
barbaria: <entryFree id="n4936" type="main" key="barba^ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>, or in post-Aug. prose <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭes</orth>, <case>acc.</case> -em; so once in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:74:258" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 74, 258</bibl>), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>barbarus</etym>. <sense id="n4936.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a foreign country</hi>, in opposition to Greece or Rome. </sense><sense id="n4936.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">a quo (philosopho) non solum Graecia et Italia, sed etiam omnis barbaria commota est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:15:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 15, 49</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 4, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:29:81" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 29, 81</bibl>; cf.: non solum cum exercitu suo, sed etiam cum omni inmanitate barbariae bellum inferre nobis. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:13:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 5, 13, 37</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 8, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid tibi barbariem. gentes ab utroque jacentes Oceano numerem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:829" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 829</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in mediā vivere barbarie,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:10:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 3, 10, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:812" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 812</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:9:5:7 al" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 9, 5, 7 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4936.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp., of a particular country, aside from Greece or Rome. Thus (in the mouth of a Greek), of <hi rend="ital">Italy</hi>, as opp. to Greece (only in Plaut.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 2, 21</bibl>; id. Fragm. ap. Fest. s. v. vapula, p. 278. <pb n="222" /> <cb n="BARB" /> —Of <hi rend="ital">Persia</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Themistoclem non in Graeciae portus, sed in barbariae sinus confugisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:3:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 3, 5</bibl></cit>.—Of <hi rend="ital">Phrygia</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Graecia barbariae lento collisa duello,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 7</bibl></cit>.—Of <hi rend="ital">Gaul</hi>, in opp. to Rome, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:20:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 20, 44</bibl> (16, 34).—Of <hi rend="ital">Scythia</hi> and <hi rend="ital">Britain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:34:88" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 34, 88</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">in gen.: quae barbaria Indiā vastior aut agrestior?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:27:77 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 27, 77 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n4936.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">mental</hi> or <hi rend="ital">moral barbarism</hi>, <hi rend="ital">according to the notion of the ancients.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4936.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Rudeness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rusticity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stupidity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbaria forensis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:26:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 26, 118</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">grandis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 8, 4</bibl></cit>.—Hence of <hi rend="ital">barbarism in language</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes tum fere, qui nec extra urbem hanc vixerant, nec eos aliqua barbaries domestica infuscaverat, recte loquebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:74:258" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 74, 258</bibl></cit>.—And of faulty reading, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 68, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4936.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Savageness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarousness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rudeness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uncivilized manners</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inveterata barbaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:19:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 19, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferum et immane facinus, quod nulla barbaria posset agnoscere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 14, 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ista vero quae et quanta barbaria est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 42, 108</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">11, 2, 6: tanta barbaries (Sarmatorum) est, ut pacem non intellegant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:12:20" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 12, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:4:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 43, 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:69" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 69</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 68</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4936.6" n="C" level="2"> = barbari: <cit><quote lang="la">quale bellum nulla umquam barbaria cum suā gente gessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:10:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 3, 10, 25</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc poëtae nomen, quod nulla umquam barbaria violavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:8:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 8, 19</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barbaricarius: <entryFree id="n4937" type="main" key="barba^ri^ca_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭcārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>barbarus</etym>, = Phrygio, <sense id="n4937.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a gold-weaver</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an embroiderer in gold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a gilder</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 12, 24, 7</bibl>; Cod. Th. 10, 22, 1; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4152</bibl>; Edict. Diocl. 16, 48, p. 84 Momms.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Donat.</author> ad Verg. A. 11, 777</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barbarice: <entryFree id="n4938" type="main" key="barba^ri^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭcē</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭcum</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. barbaricus <sense id="n4938.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
barbaricus: <entryFree id="n4939" type="greek" key="barba^ri^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">barbariko/s</foreign> [barbarus]. <sense id="n4939.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>, <hi rend="ital">outlandish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarous</hi>, in opp. to Grecian or Roman (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post - Aug. prose). </sense><sense id="n4939.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">alae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:476" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 476</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sermo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 18, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pyra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 15, 16, § 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 6, 7, 1</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n4939.2" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭcum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> </sense><sense id="n4939.3" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">A foreign land</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Albis in barbarico, longe ultra Rhenum est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 7, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">9, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Sev. 47</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4939.4" n="b" level="4"> Barbaricum appellatur clamor exercitus, quod eo genere barbari utantur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=31" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 31</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n4939.5" n="B" level="2"> Esp., of a particular country, in opp. to Greece or Rome. </sense><sense id="n4939.6" n="1" level="3"> Freq. for <hi rend="ital">Phrygian</hi> (v. barbarus): astante ope barbaricā, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:19:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 19, 44</bibl> (Trag. v. 120 Müll.): <cit><quote lang="la">vestes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:500" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 500</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbarico postes auro spoliisque superbi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:504" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 504</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4939.7" n="2" level="3"> (In the mouth of a Greek.) For <hi rend="ital">Italian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Roman</hi> (only in Plaut.): <cit><quote lang="la">urbes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lex,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cenare lepide nitideque volo: nihil moror barbarico ritu esse,</quote> <trans><tr>after the frugal manner of the ancient Romans</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:6:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 3, 6, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4939.8" n="3" level="3"> For <hi rend="ital">German</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Germanic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:47" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 47</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4939.9" n="II" level="1"> (Acc. to barbarus, II.) <hi rend="ital">Rough</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rude</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unpolished</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">vita,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Eutr. 2, 226</bibl></cit>. —<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">silva barbarica id est conseminea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:83" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 83</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:58:5" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 58, 5</bibl>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos> </sense><sense id="n4939.10" n="a" level="4"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭcum</orth>, <hi rend="ital">barbarously</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbaricum atque immane gemens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:418" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 418</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4939.11" n="b" level="4"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭcē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">like a foreigner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">barba barbarice demissa,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Ver. 10, § 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barbaries: <entryFree id="n4940" type="main" key="barba^ri^es"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărĭes</orth>, v. barbaria.</entryFree>
barbarismus: <entryFree id="n4941" type="greek" key="barba^rismus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărismus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">barbarismo/s</foreign>, <sense id="n4941.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an impropriety of speech</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarism;</hi> esp. of pronunciation (acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:6:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 6, 14</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:20:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 20, 1</bibl>, not in use before the Aug. per.; <cit><quote lang="la">in Nigidius, instead of it, rusticus sermo),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:5 sq" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 5 sq.</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 12, 17</bibl>; Gell. l. l.; 5, 20, 4; Don. p. 1767 sq. P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 237 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Diom. p. 446 sq.</bibl> P. al.; cf. the foll.</sense></entryFree>
barbarolexis: <entryFree id="n4942" type="greek" key="barba^ro^lexis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărŏlexis</orth>, <itype>eos</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">barbaro/lecis</foreign>, <sense id="n4942.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the perversion of the form of a word</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">the change</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in flection of a Greek word according to Latin usage</hi> (while barbarismus is the erroneous pronunciation of a Latin word), <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 1, 31, 2</bibl> (in <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 237</bibl> P. used as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
barbarum: <entryFree id="n4943" type="main" key="barba^rum1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. barbarus, I. A.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4944" type="main" key="barba^rum2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>barbarus</etym>; in medicine, <sense id="n4944.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plaster applied to raw wounds</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">optimum ex his (emplastris) est, quod barbarum vocatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 19</bibl></cit>, n. 1; 5. 26, n. 23; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 207" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 207</bibl> (in Scrib. Lang. Comp. l. l. <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbăra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>). <cb n="BARB" /></sense></entryFree>
barbarus: <entryFree id="n4945" type="greek" key="barba^rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> (<sense id="n4945.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur. m.</hi> barbarum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 39</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">15, 25</bibl>), <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">ba/rbaros</foreign> [cf. barrio; balo, balbus; blatio]. </sense><sense id="n4945.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop., <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarous</hi>, opp. to Greek or Roman. </sense><sense id="n4945.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">hospes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:7:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 7, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mixta facit Graiis barbara turba metum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:10:28" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 10, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:29:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 29, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">reges,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 35, 11</bibl></cit>.—Hence, in Tac., in barbarum, adverb., <hi rend="ital">in the manner</hi> or <hi rend="ital">according to the custom of foreigners</hi> or <hi rend="ital">barbarians</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">civitas potens, neque in barbarum corrupta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 42</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 5, 2</bibl>.— As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a foreigner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stranger</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sin hoc et ratio doctis et necessitas barbaris praescripsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:11:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 11, 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:50:section=112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 50, § 112</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 5, 60, § 157</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo neque noster adit quisquam, nec barbarus audet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quippe simul nobis habitat discrimine nullo Barbarus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:10:30" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 10, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbarorum soli prope Germani singulis uxoribus contenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbari praestabant non modicam humanitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:28:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 28, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4945.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., of a particular people, in opp. to Greek or Roman or both; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Romanus Graiusque ac barbarus induperator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:138" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 138</bibl></cit> (cf.: barbaria, barbaricus, and Fest. s. v. barbari, p. 36 Müll.). </sense><sense id="n4945.4" n="1" level="3"> (In the mouth of a Greek, or in opp. to Greek.) <hi rend="ital">Italian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Roman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Latin</hi> (never so used by the Romans): <cit><quote lang="la">nam os columnatum poetae esse inaudivi barbaro (sc. Naevio) (words of the Ephesian Periplectomenes),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:3:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 1, 3, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">i, stultior es barbaro Poticio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 2, 15</bibl></cit>: absurdum erat aut tantum barbaris casibus Graecam litteram (<foreign lang="greek">f</foreign>) adhibere, aut recto casu Graece loqui, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:48:160" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 48, 160</bibl>.—So also, </sense><sense id="n4945.5" n="b" level="4"> In the mouth of a Macedonian: <cit><quote lang="la">cum alienigenis, cum barbaris aeternum omnibus Graecis bellum est eritque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:29:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 29, 15</bibl></cit>.—And, </sense><sense id="n4945.6" n="c" level="4"> In reference to the inhabitants of Pontus: <cit><quote lang="la">barbarus hic ego sum, quia non intellegor ulli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:10:37" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 10, 37</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4945.7" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Phrygian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tibia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:264" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 264</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:546" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 546</bibl> Forbig.: <cit><quote lang="la">sonante mixtum tibiis carmen lyrae, Hac Dorium, illis barbarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:9:6" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 9, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:777" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 777</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 163</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4945.8" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Persian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a Persian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">solere reges barbaros Persarum ac Syrorum pluris uxores habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:33:section=76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 33, § 76</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 7, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Them. 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:11:16" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 11, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:10" default="NO">5, 10</bibl>. 2.—Thus the king of the Persians is called barbarus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 4, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Con. 4, 3</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and high officers of the king, barbari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ages. 3, 1</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Romanum agmen ad similitudinem barbari incessus convertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 33</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n4945.9" n="4" level="3"> In gen., for <hi rend="ital">any hostile people</hi> (among the Romans, after the Aug. age, esp. the German tribes, as, among the Greeks, after the Persian war, the Persians): <cit><quote lang="la">opinio, quae animos gentium barbararum pervaserat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 9, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:27:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 27, 76</bibl>; of <hi rend="ital">the Gauls</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:42:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 42, 7</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">the Germans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">47</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">51</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 18, 2, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sunt fluxioris fidei barbari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 18, 2, 18</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">the Thracians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Alcib. 7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Alcib. 7, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 47</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">11, 51</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Carthaginians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,020:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Timol. 1, 1</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Cilicians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Thras. 4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Thras. 4, 4</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Phœnicians</hi> and <hi rend="ital">Cyprians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,005:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cim. 2, 3</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Parthians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 26</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Africans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 25</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Britons</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 17</bibl>; 12, 35; 14, 32; even of the <hi rend="ital">Dassaretians</hi>, a Greek people, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:33:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 33, 5</bibl>; while the Romans did not elsewhere use barbarus for Greek.—</sense><sense id="n4945.10" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>, in mind or character. </sense><sense id="n4945.11" n="A" level="2"> In mind, <hi rend="ital">uncultivated</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ignorant; rude</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unpolished</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui aliis inhumanus ac barbarus, isti uni commodus ac disertus videretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:9:section=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 9, § 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ecqua civitas est... aut tam potens aut tam libera aut etiam tam inmanis ac barbara, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 11</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">24: nationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:16:27" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 16, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Maroboduus... natione magis quam ratione barbarus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:108:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 108, 2</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, of verses: <cit><quote lang="la">non sunt illa suo barbariora loco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:1:72" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 1, 72</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4945.12" n="B" level="2"> Of character, <hi rend="ital">wild</hi>, <hi rend="ital">savage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cruel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque tam barbari linguā et natione illi, quam tu naturā et moribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:50:section=112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 50, § 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immanis ac barbara consuetudo hominum immolandorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:14:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 14, 31</bibl></cit> (10, 21); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 6, 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 9, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">gens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:27:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 27, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:32:section=81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 32, § 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 5, 57</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">148: pirata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:50:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 50, 146</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:55:section=122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 55, § 122</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:48" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tollite barbarum Morem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1</bibl></cit>, <cb n="BARB" /> 27, 2: <cit><quote lang="la">Medea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 5, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:27:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 3, 27, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libidines,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:574" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 574</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">populus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:113:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 113, 1</bibl></cit>.— * <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacra barbariora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:3:2:78" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 3, 2, 78</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> not in use.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">barbărē</orth>. </sense><sense id="n4945.13" n="A" level="2"> Prop., <hi rend="ital">as a foreigner would</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in a foreign tongue</hi>: Demophilus scripsit; <cit><quote lang="la">Marcus vortit barbare,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>into Latin</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:prol. 10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. prol. 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:prol. 19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. prol. 19</bibl>; cf. barbarus, I. B. 1. —</sense><sense id="n4945.14" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4945.15" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Rudely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ignorantly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in an uncultivated way</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si grammaticum se professus quispiam barbare loqueretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:4:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut is, a quo insolenter quid aut minaciter aut crudeliter dictum sit, barbare locutus existimetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:9" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tota saepe theatra et omnem Circi turbam exclamasse barbare scimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:6:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 6, 45</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4945.16" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Rudely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">roughly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarously</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cruelly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dulcia barbare Laedentem oscula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:13:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 13, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferociter et barbare facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 15, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barbatia: <entryFree id="n4946" type="main" key="Barbati^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barbatĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4946.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Arabia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 146</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barbatoria: <entryFree id="n4947" type="hapax" key="barba_to_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbātōrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>barba</etym>, <sense id="n4947.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shaving of the beard</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere,</quote> <trans><tr>to shave the beard for the first time</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 73, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barbatulus: <entryFree id="n4948" type="main" key="barba_tu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbātŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n4948.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [barbatus], <hi rend="ital">having a small</hi> or <hi rend="ital">foppish beard</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">concursabant barbatuli juvenes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:14:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 14, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 16, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 117</bibl>, n. 6 and 10.— <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> to fishes: <cit><quote lang="la">barbatuli mulli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:5:2:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 5, 2, 38</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barbatus: <entryFree id="n4949" type="main" key="barba_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>barba</etym>. <sense id="n4949.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Having a beard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bearded.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4949.1" n="A" level="2"> Of men: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere licebit Jovem semper barbatum, Apollinem semper imberbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:30:83" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 30, 83</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 36, 100</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos aut imberbes aut bene barbatos videtis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:10:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 10, 22</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> as a designation of age, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:8:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 8, 25</bibl>: equitare in harundine longā, Si quem delectet barbatum, i. e. <hi rend="ital">an adult</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:249" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 249</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sub Jove, sed Jove nondum barbato,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>in the earliest time</tr>, <tr>when Jupiter was yet young</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:16" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:56" default="NO">13, 56</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n4949.2" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4949.3" n="a" level="4"> For <hi rend="ital">a Roman of the olden time</hi> (in which the beard was not shaved, v. barba): <cit><quote lang="la">aliquis mihi ab inferis excitandus est ex barbatis illis, non hac barbulā, sed illā horridā, quam in statuis antiquis et imaginibus videmus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:14:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 14, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unus aliquis ex barbatis illis, exemplum imperii veteris, imago antiquitatis, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sest 8, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec jam tum apud illos barbatos ridicula, credo, videbantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:12:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 12, 26</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:23:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 23, 62</bibl>: hic mos jam apud illos antiquos et barbatos fuit, id. Fragm. Or. II. pro Cornel. 18; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:103" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 103</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4949.4" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">A philosopher</hi> (since they wore long beards), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:4:1" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:12" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 12</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 133</bibl>; and as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> barbatus nudus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:81" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 81</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4949.5" n="B" level="2"> Of animals, fishes, etc., <hi rend="ital">bearded</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hirculus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:19:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 19, 16</bibl></cit>; also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> barbatus, <hi rend="ital">a goat</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:4:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 4, 9, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 1, 7</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:5:2:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 5, 2, 28</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 17, 30, § 64</bibl>): aquila, <hi rend="ital">a species of eagle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also called</hi> ossifraga, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 3, 3, § 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4949.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4949.7" n="A" level="2"> Of plants (cf. barba, II. A.), <hi rend="ital">woolly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">downy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nux,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 1, 2, § 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4949.8" n="B" level="2"> Of other things: <cit><quote lang="la">ne toga barbatos faciat vel paenula libros,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>wear out</tr>, <tr>make bearded</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:84" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 84</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4949.9" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A cognomen of</hi> Lucius Corn. Scipio, Inscr.</sense></entryFree>
barbesco: <entryFree id="n4950" type="gloss" key="barbesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbesco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">geneia/zw</foreign>, <sense id="n4950.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to get a beard</hi>, Gloss. Cyril.</sense></entryFree>
barbiger: <entryFree id="n4951" type="main" key="barbi^ger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbĭger</orth>, <itype>ĕra, ĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>barba-gero</etym>, <sense id="n4951.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wearing a beard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bearded</hi> (only in Lucr.): <cit><quote lang="la">capellae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:971" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 971</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecudes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:898" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 898</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barbio: <entryFree id="n4952" type="main" key="barbi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbĭo</orth>, <itype>īre, 4</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>barba</etym>, <sense id="n4952.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to raise a beard</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> p. 4, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barbitium: <entryFree id="n4953" type="main" key="barbi^ti^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbĭtĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, = barba, <sense id="n4953.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the beard</hi> (perh. only in App.), <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 5, p. 162, 21</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">11</bibl>, p. 260, 40.</sense></entryFree>
barbiton: <entryFree id="n4954" type="main" key="barbi^to^n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbĭtŏn</orth>, v. barbitos.</entryFree>
barbitos: <entryFree id="n4955" type="greek" key="barbi^to^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbĭtŏs</orth>, <gen>m.</gen> (<gen>f.</gen> in the spurious epistle of Sappho, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 8</bibl>; <sense id="n4955.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>; found only in <case>nom.</case>, <case>acc.</case>, and <hi rend="ital">voc.; plur.</hi> <itype>barbita</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 44</bibl>). = <foreign lang="greek">ba/rbiton (-os</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">a lyre</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a lute</hi> (not before the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">age, dic Latinum, Barbite, carmen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:32:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 32, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 1, 34</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 26, 4</bibl>; Claud. Praef. ap. Nupt. Hon. et Mar. 10; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epigr. 44</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4955.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the song played upon the lute</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non facit ad lacrimas barbitos ulla meas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15</bibl></cit>. 8 (a spurious poem).</sense></entryFree>
barbosthenes: <entryFree id="n4956" type="main" key="Barbosthe^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barbosthĕnes</orth>, v. Barnosthenes.</entryFree>
barbula: <entryFree id="n4957" type="main" key="barbu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbŭla</orth>, ae. <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>barba</etym>. <sense id="n4957.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A little beard</hi> (as worn by the young Romans; v. barba. barbatus, and barbatulus): non hac barbulā, sed illa horrida, quam in statuis <pb n="223" /> <cb n="BARG" /> antiquis videmus, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:14:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 14, 33</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4957.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> to plants (cf. barba, II. A.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 11, 74, § 98</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:49" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 8, 25, § 49</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4957.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A cognomen of</hi> Q. Aemilius, Liv 9, 20, 7.</sense></entryFree>
barbus: <entryFree id="n4958" type="main" key="barbus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barbus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>barba</etym>, <sense id="n4958.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a barbel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a river barbel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cyprinus barbus, Linn.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Mosell. 94</bibl></cit> and 134 (cf. barbatulus mullus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:5:2:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 5, 2, 38</bibl>, and barbati mulli, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 1, 7</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
barca: <entryFree id="n4959" type="main" key="barca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4959.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small boat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barge</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">barca est, quae cuncta navis commercia ad litus portat. Hanc navis in pelago propter nimias undas suo suscipit gremio, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 19, 1, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Carm. 21, 95</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barcaei: <entryFree id="n4960" type="main" key="Barcaei"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcaei</orth>, v Barce.</entryFree>
barcas: <entryFree id="n4961" type="main" key="Barcas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcas</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Barca</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ba/rkas</foreign> [<foreign />, a gleaming, or a gleaming sword, as an epithet of heroes; cf. Gesenius, Gesch. d. Hebr. Spr. und Schr, p. 229], <sense id="n4961.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ancestor of a distinguished family in Carthage to which Hamilcar and Hannibal belonged</hi>, hence, <hi rend="ital">a surname of Hamilcar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,022:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ham. 1, 1</bibl>.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n4961.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv </sense><sense id="n4961.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Barcas</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the family</hi> or <hi rend="ital">party of Barcas</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">familia Barcina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:13:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 13, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">factio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 9, 4</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Bar-cīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Barcini</hi>, Liv 21, 3, 3.— <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Barcina clades,</quote> <trans><tr>near the river Metaurus</tr>, <tr>where Hasdrubal was conquered and slain</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Carm. 2, 532</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4961.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Bar-caeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Barcas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Barcœan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">juvenis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Hannibal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:355" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 10, 355</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:200" default="NO">12, 200</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barce: <entryFree id="n4962" type="main" key="Barce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ba/rkh</foreign>. <sense id="n4962.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in the Libyan province Pentapolis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">afterwards called Ptolemais</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Tolometa</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Dolmeita</hi> (acc. to others, <hi rend="ital">the ruins of Merdsjeh</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 5, 5, § 32</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcaei</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Barce</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enemies of Dido</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> prolepsis), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 43</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4962.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The nurse of Sichœus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:632" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 632</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barcino: <entryFree id="n4963" type="main" key="Barci^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcĭno</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-on</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4963.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the present city Barcelona</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Spain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 3, 4, § 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:6:5" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 6, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 24, 89</bibl>; Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 33.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcĭnōnensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Barcelona</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">muria,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 21 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
barcinus: <entryFree id="n4964" type="main" key="Barci_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barcīnus</orth>, <itype>v Barcas</itype>, II. A.</entryFree>
bardaei: <entryFree id="n4965" type="main" key="Bardaei"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bardaei</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4965.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Illyrian people</hi> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 9, 2</bibl>, Vardaei)—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Bardăĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Bardœan</hi> calceus, <hi rend="ital">a kind of soldier</hi>'<hi rend="ital">s boot</hi>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">the soldiers themselves</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:16:13" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 16, 13</bibl> (cf. Caligula)' cuculli, <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Pertin. 8, 3</bibl>; cf. bardocucullus.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Bardăĭcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a soldier</hi>'<hi rend="ital">s boot</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 4</bibl>. 5.</sense></entryFree>
barditus: <entryFree id="n4966" type="main" key="bardi_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bardītus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>bardus</etym>, <sense id="n4966.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the war-song of the Germans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 3</bibl> Holder ad loc.; cf. baritus.</sense></entryFree>
bardocucullus: <entryFree id="n4967" type="main" key="bardo^cu^cullus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bardŏcŭcullus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4967.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Gallic overcoat</hi> (<hi rend="ital">cloak</hi>), <hi rend="ital">with a hood</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cowl</hi>, <hi rend="ital">made of woollen stuff</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:128" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 128</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:54:5" default="NO">1, 54, 5</bibl>, Gallien. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Treb. Pol.</author> Claud. 17, 6</bibl> (in Capitol. Pertin. cucullus Bardaicus); v. Bardaïcus, s. v Bardaei <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
bardulis: <entryFree id="n4968" type="main" key="Bardu_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bardūlis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ba/rdulis</foreign>, <sense id="n4968.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a king of Illyria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who waged war against Philip of Macedon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:11:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 11, 40</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
bardus:
<entryFree id="n4969" type="main" key="bardus" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bardus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n4969.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj</hi> [root garu-, whence also gravis; Sanscr. guruú; cf. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">baru/s, bradu/s</foreign>, and Lat. brutus], <hi rend="ital">stupid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dull of apprehension</hi> (rare), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 10, 3 sq.</bibl>; Adamant. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> p. 2299</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">stulti, stolidi, fatui, fungi, bardi, blenni, buccones, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:3:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 3, 3, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:2:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 2, 1, 2</bibl> (quoted by Non. l. l.): Zopyrus stupidum esse Socratem dixit et bardum, * <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat 5, 10</bibl>: Pictor bardior, Tert. adv Herm. 36.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> and <pos>adv.</pos> not in use.
†† </sense><sense id="n4969.1" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">bardus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Engl. bard; Celtic, from Wal. bar, = spirit, or Armor. bar, = distinguished</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a poet and singer among the Gauls</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">minstrel.</hi> bardus Gallice cantor appellatur, qui virorum fortium laudes canit, a gente Bardorum, de quibus Lucanus, 1, 449; Fest. p 28; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 15, 9, 5</bibl> and 8.</sense></entryFree>
barea: <entryFree id="n4970" type="main" key="Bare_a1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barēa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4970.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in</hi> Hispania Tarraconensis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 4, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 3, 4, § 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4971" type="main" key="Bare^a2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barĕa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4971.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman cognomen</hi>, e. g. Q. Marcius Barea, consul A.U.C. 779: <cit><quote lang="la">Barea Soranus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 16, 23</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:91" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 91</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
bargullum: <entryFree id="n4972" type="main" key="Bargullum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargullum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n4972.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of Epirus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:12:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 12, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
bargus: <entryFree id="n4973" type="main" key="Bargus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4973.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Thrace</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tributary to the Ebrus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 11, 18, § 50</bibl>. <cb n="BASA" /></sense></entryFree>
bargusii: <entryFree id="n4974" type="main" key="Bargu_si^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargūsĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*bargou/sioi</foreign>, Polyb., <sense id="n4974.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in</hi> Hispania Tarraconensis, <hi rend="ital">near the Pyrenees</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:19:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 19, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes">23, 2 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
bargyliae: <entryFree id="n4975" type="main" key="Bargy^li^ae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargylĭae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*bargu/lia</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*ba/rgula, ta/</foreign>, in Strabo; <foreign lang="greek">*barguli/a, h(</foreign>, in Stephan. Byzant., <sense id="n4975.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Caria</hi>, Liv 32, 33, 7; 33, 18, 18.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n4975.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n4975.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargylĭētĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Bargyliœ</hi>: sinus. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:17:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 17, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">campi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 31, § 113</bibl></cit>.—And from the parallel form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargylĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*bargu/lia, ta/</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 29, § 107</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4975.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargylētae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Bargylice</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:56:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 56, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
bargylus: <entryFree id="n4976" type="main" key="Bargylus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bargylus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4976.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain of Phœnicia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 20, 17, § 78</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barine: <entryFree id="n4977" type="main" key="Bari_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barīnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4977.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a freedwoman</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> C 2, 8, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barinulae: <entryFree id="n4978" type="gloss" key="bari_nulae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barīnulae</orth> = aquileges, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. G. 1, 109</bibl></entryFree>
barippe: <entryFree id="n4979" type="main" key="barippe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barippē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, v. baroptenus.</entryFree>
baris: <entryFree id="n4980" type="foreign" key="ba_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bāris</orth>, <itype>ĭdos</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>Egyptian</etym>, <sense id="n4980.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small Egyptian row-boat</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">ba/ris</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3</bibl> (4), 11, 44 Kuin.</sense></entryFree>
baritus: <entryFree id="n4981" type="foreign" key="bari_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barītus</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">barrītus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">bardītus</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>cf. bassio and O. Germ. bar, baren, to raise the voice</etym>, <sense id="n4981.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the war-cry of the Germans;</hi> and in gen., <hi rend="ital">battle-cry</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clamor, quem baritum vocant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 3, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cornuti et bracati baritum civere vel maximum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 12, 43</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">21, 13, 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">26, 7, 14</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">31, 7, 11.—Of the battle-song: carmina, quorum relatu, quem barditum vocant, accendunt animos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> G 3</bibl></cit> Halm; v. Comm. in h. l.</sense></entryFree>
barium: <entryFree id="n4982" type="main" key="Bari^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ba/rion</foreign>, <sense id="n4982.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Apulia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Adriatic Sea</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Bari</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:4:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 4, 7</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 16, § 102</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:18:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 18, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 16, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">piscosum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 97</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barnosthenes: <entryFree id="n4983" type="main" key="Barnosthe^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barnosthĕnes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4983.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain in Laconia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">east of Sparta</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:27:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 27, 13</bibl> (MSS. <orth extent="full" lang="la">Barbosthenes</orth>, Weissenb. ad loc.); 35, 30, 9.</sense></entryFree>
baro: <entryFree id="n4984" type="main" key="ba_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bāro</orth>, ōnis <gen>m.</gen> <etym>kindr with bardus, q. v.; cf. also Varro, varo</etym>, <sense id="n4984.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a simpleton</hi>, <hi rend="ital">blockhead</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dunce</hi> (four times in Cicero, elsewhere rare): <cit><quote lang="la">haec cum loqueris, nos barones stupemus, tu videlicet tecum ipse rides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:23:76" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 23, 76</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:70:144" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 70, 144</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:26:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 26, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:11:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 11, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:138" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 138</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 53, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">63, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
baroptenus: <entryFree id="n4985" type="main" key="baropte^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">baroptĕnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">barippē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4985.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an unknown precious stone of a black color</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with white and red spots</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 55, § 150</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barosus: <entryFree id="n4986" type="gloss" key="ba_ro_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bārōsus</orth> <foreign lang="greek">ba/khlos, sobaro/s</foreign>, stultus, mulierosus, mollis, Gloss. Philox.</entryFree>
barpana: <entryFree id="n4987" type="main" key="Barpa_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barpāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4987.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an island east of Corsica</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:19" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 6, 12, § 81</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barrinus: <entryFree id="n4988" type="hapax" key="barri_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barrīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n4988.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj</hi> [barrus], <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to an elephant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">elephantine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aures,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 3, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barrio: <entryFree id="n4989" type="main" key="barri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barrĭo</orth>, <itype>īre</itype>, <sense id="n4989.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to cry;</hi> of elephants. barrire elephantes dicuntur, sicut oves dicimus balare, utique a sono ipso vo cis: <cit><quote lang="la">elephanti barriunt, ranae coaxant, equi hinniunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Get 5, 5</bibl></cit>; Auct. Carm. Phil. 53; cf. Paul. ex Fest p. 30 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
barritus: <entryFree id="n4990" type="main" key="barri_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barrītus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>barrio</etym>, <sense id="n4990.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the cry of the elephant</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. 16, p. 358, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 3, 24</bibl>; cf. Isid. Orig. under barrus.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4991" type="main" key="barri_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">barrītus</orth>, v baritus.
†† <sense id="n4991.0" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">barrus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">i</orth>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Indian; Sanscr bhri, to bear</etym>, <hi rend="ital">an elephant</hi>' apud Indos (elephantus) a voce (cf. barrio) barrus vocatur: <cit><quote lang="la">unde et vox ejus barritus dicitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 12, 2, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">16, 5, 19</bibl>. <foreign lang="greek">'*ele/fas</foreign>, elephantus, barrus, Gloss. Philox.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Serv,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:592" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 592</bibl></cit>; * Hor Epod. 12, 1 Porphyr.</sense></entryFree>
barrus: <entryFree id="n4992" type="main" key="Barrus" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Barrus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">i</orth>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4992.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cognomen of</hi> T, Betucius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:46:169" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 46, 169</bibl></sense></entryFree>
barycephalus: <entryFree id="n4993" type="greek" key="ba^ry^ce^pha^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bărycĕphălus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">barnke/falos</foreign>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">bărycus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n4993.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj</hi> [<foreign lang="greek">baru/s</foreign>], in archit., <hi rend="ital">top-heavy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with low walls and broad roofs</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 3, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barypicron: <entryFree id="n4994" type="greek" key="ba^ry^pi_^cron"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bărypī^cron</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ī</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">baru/pikron</foreign> (very bitter), <sense id="n4994.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Greek epithet of wormwood</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">absinthium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 100</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
barython: <entryFree id="n4995" type="greek" key="ba^ry^thon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bărython</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">baruqwn</foreign>, <sense id="n4995.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also called</hi> Sabina, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 85</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
barytonos: <entryFree id="n4996" type="greek" key="ba^ry^to^no^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bărytŏnŏs</orth>, <itype>ŏn</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">baru/tonos</foreign>, <sense id="n4996.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">not accented on the last syllable</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Diff. 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 1 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
basaboiates: <entryFree id="n4997" type="main" key="Basaboia_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Basaboiātes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4997.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of</hi> Gallia Aquitania, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 19, 33, § 108</bibl>. <cb n="BASI" /></sense></entryFree>
basaltes: <entryFree id="n4998" type="foreign" key="basaltes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">basaltes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>African</etym>, <sense id="n4998.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a dark and very hard species of marble in Ethiopia</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 16, 5, 6</bibl>; cf. Strabo, 17, p. 818.</sense></entryFree>
basanites: <entryFree id="n4999" type="greek" key="ba^sa^ni_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băsănītes lăpis</orth> = <foreign lang="greek">basaniths (ba/sanos</foreign>), <sense id="n4999.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a touchstone</hi>, <hi rend="ital">test-stone</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a very hard stone</hi>, <hi rend="ital">used as a test for the precious metals</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for whetstones</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in medicine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for mortars</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 20, 38, § 147</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:157" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 22, 43, § 157</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 16, 4, 36</bibl>.—Also basanites alone, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 7, 11, § 58</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
bascauda: <entryFree id="n5000" type="foreign" key="bascauda"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bascauda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>British; whence Engl. basket; cf. Wall. basget, basgawd; and Gr <foreign lang="greek">basta/zw</foreign>, to carry</etym>, <sense id="n5000.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an article of table furniture</hi>, prob. <hi rend="ital">a delicately woven mat</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">dish-holder of basket-work</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:12:46" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 12, 46</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:99:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 99, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
basella: <entryFree id="n5001" type="hapax" key="ba^sella"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băsella</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <sense id="n5001.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">f dim.</hi> [basis], <hi rend="ital">a small base</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 18, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
basiatio: <entryFree id="n5002" type="main" key="ba_si^a_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bāsĭātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <sense id="n5002.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">f</hi> [basio], <hi rend="ital">a kissing;</hi> meton (abstr pro concr.), <hi rend="ital">a kiss</hi> (rare; cf. osculum), *<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 7, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:95:17" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 95, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:23:4" default="NO">2, 23, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
basiator: <entryFree id="n5003" type="main" key="ba_si^a_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">bāsĭātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n5003.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kisser</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one who kisses</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:11:98:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 11, 98, 1</bibl> sqq. (perh. not elsewhere).</sense></entryFree>
basilea: <entryFree id="n5004" type="main" key="Ba^si^le_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Băsĭlēa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-īa</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n5004.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the town Basel</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Bāle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Switzerland</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 30, 3, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
basilia: <entryFree id="n5005" type="main" key="Ba^si^li_a1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Băsĭlīa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">basi/leia, ta/</foreign> (regal), <sense id="n5005.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of the books of Kings in the Bible</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n5006" type="main" key="Ba^si^li_a2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Băsĭlīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n5006.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">another name for the island Balcia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 13, 27, § 95</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:36" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 2, 11, § 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
basiliadae: <entryFree id="n5007" type="main" key="Ba^si^li^a^dae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Băsĭlĭădae</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-lidae</orth>), <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n5007.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of Sarmatia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 26, § 84</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:1:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 1, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
basilica: <entryFree id="n5008" type="main" key="ba^si^li^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băsĭlĭca</orth>, v. basilicus, II. B.</entryFree>
basilice: <entryFree id="n5009" type="main" key="ba^si^li^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băsĭlĭcē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. basilicus, I. A. <sense id="n5009.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
basiliciarius: <entryFree id="n5010" type="gloss" key="ba^si^li^ci^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băsĭlĭcĭārĭus</orth>, <foreign lang="greek">malako/s, a)goraios</foreign>, Gloss. Gr Lat.</entryFree>
basilicola: <entryFree id="n5011" type="main" key="ba^si^li^co^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băsĭlĭcŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>basilica</etym>, <sense id="n5011.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small church</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a little chapel</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Ep. ad Sev 32</bibl>, n. 17.</sense></entryFree>
basilicon: <entryFree id="n5012" type="main" key="ba^si^li^con"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băsĭlĭcon</orth>, v. basilicus, II. C. 2.</entryFree>
